column2: The opening shot is one of the most incredible things I've ever seen in a movie. Absolutely breathtaking.
I knew it was too good to be true when Kowalski showed up in the capsule. The dream sequence broke me.
This movie is a 90-minute anxiety attack in the best way possible.
The way she uses the fire extinguisher as a thruster to get to the Chinese station was pure genius.
The silence of space is deafening in this film. The sound design is 10/10.
The final scene, with her just breathing on Earth after all that... goosebumps.
Sandra Bullock deserves all the awards for this performance. She carried the whole movie.
The reveal that the Soyuz parachute was already deployed was such a soul-crushing moment.
The 3D in this movie is probably the best use of the technology ever.
The moment Kowalski has to let go and drifts into the void... I'm not over it.
This film makes you appreciate just how hostile space really is.
Her 'conversation' with Aningaaq on the radio, not understanding a word but finding connection, was so beautiful.
The debris field sequences are terrifying. It's like a cosmic bullet storm.
The way she finally decides to fight and 'learn to drive' to get home is so empowering.
George Clooney was so charming and calming, even as everything was going to hell.
That moment when she realizes she has to let go of her daughter's memory to survive... powerful stuff.
The feeling of isolation in this movie is overwhelming.
The fire in the ISS scene was so claustrophobic and intense.
This movie is a masterclass in tension.
The ending where she has to re-learn how to walk on Earth is such a perfect final image.
The cinematography makes you feel like you are right there in space with them.
The moment when she thinks she's going to die and just turns off the oxygen is so bleak.
I can't believe this was mostly CGI. It all looked so real.
Her seeing her daughter in the dream gives her the final push she needs to survive. So emotional.
The theme of rebirth is so strong in this movie.
The final re-entry sequence is one of the most thrilling scenes ever filmed.
The way the story is just a chain reaction of disasters is relentless.
The moment she makes contact with Earth, even if it's just a dog barking, feels like a miracle.
This movie made me never want to go to space. Ever.
The symbolism of her emerging from the water at the end, like the first life on Earth, is brilliant.
The long takes are just a technical marvel.
Kowalski's sacrifice is the definition of letting go so someone else can live.
The details, like her tears floating in zero-g, are what make this movie so special.
The whole film is just a pure survival story, and it's gripping from start to finish.
The way she uses every last bit of her training to survive is inspiring.
The moment of peace when she's just floating in the fetal position is so poignant before the chaos starts again.
The sound going from the muffled helmet audio to complete silence is so effective.
Her final monologue before re-entry, where she's just ready for any outcome, is a great character moment.
The score is amazing, it ramps up the tension perfectly.
Her journey from wanting to die to fighting for her life is incredible.
This is one of the most immersive movie experiences I've ever had.
The way she has to problem-solve her way out of each disaster is so compelling.
The visual of the space stations being torn apart is haunting.
The final stand, learning to walk again on solid ground, is a triumph of the human spirit.
The shots of Earth from orbit are just jaw-droppingly beautiful.
The dream of Kowalski is the turning point where she finds the will to live.
It's a surprisingly emotional movie for being about one person in space.
The way she learns to move in zero-g throughout the film shows her adaptation and survival.
This movie is an edge-of-your-seat thriller from beginning to end.
The final moments of her feeling the mud and grass are so grounding after 90 minutes of space.
The way the debris field comes back around on a predictable schedule is a great ticking clock device.
Her using the Soyuz landing rockets to propel herself towards the Shenzhou was a big brain move.
The themes of letting go and rebirth are woven throughout the entire film.
Clooney's character provides just enough hope and guidance before his tragic exit.
The shot of her floating away into the blackness is pure nightmare fuel.
The final scene is a perfect bookend to her journey from being lost in space to being found on Earth.
You really feel the weight of every action and every second that passes.
The fact that the initial disaster was caused by a Russian missile strike is a chillingly realistic detail.
This is a movie about resilience, plain and simple.
When she finally gets the Shenzhou to power up, it's such a moment of relief.
The scale is epic, but the story is incredibly intimate and personal.
The way she has to physically pull herself through each space station is such a struggle.
A beautiful and terrifying film.
The moment she realizes she has to detach from Kowalski to save him from being pulled away is heartbreaking.
The contrast between the beautiful views of Earth and the deadly chaos is stark.
Her final decision to try, even if it might fail, is what saves her.
The technical achievement of this film is still mind-blowing.
Kowalski's spirit (or her memory of him) literally saves her life by giving her the solution she overlooked.
The movie is a testament to the will to survive.
The destruction of the ISS was a horrifying spectacle.
It's a simple story told with incredible technical skill and emotional depth.
The way she has to overcome her grief to survive is the real story.
I held my breath for about 90% of this movie.
The final shot of her standing up on her own two feet is one of the most earned triumphs in cinema.
The use of first-person perspective puts you right in the helmet with her.
The moment she gets the radio to work and just hears a dog barking is so grounding.
This is pure cinema. A visual and auditory experience.
The way she uses the Russian manual despite not speaking the language is peak resourcefulness.
The film's tension comes from its terrifyingly realistic depiction of space.
Her prayer at the end, saying she's ready to go, is a moment of profound acceptance before her final fight.
The soundscape of the film is just as important as the visuals.
The ending is a powerful statement about human resilience and the will to live.
The single-take shots are a technical marvel.
The way she talks about her daughter is the emotional anchor of the entire film.
This is a film you feel as much as you watch.
Kowalski's sacrifice is both heroic and tragic, a necessary loss for her survival.
The beauty and horror of space have never been captured better.
Her final landing in the water is a clear baptism/rebirth symbol. 10/10 filmmaking.
The movie is a constant series of out-of-the-frying-pan-into-the-fire moments.
The way she perseveres through impossible odds is truly inspiring.
It's a story of survival, but also a story of learning to live again after loss.
That final, shaky step on land is more triumphant than any superhero landing.
The film's use of silence is more effective than any loud explosion.
She had to let go of both her daughter and Kowalski to finally make it home.
A cinematic masterpiece that has to be seen to be believed.
The ending shot is a direct callback to the evolution of life from water to land. Genius.
